What's the best way to paint around electrical outlets?

Here’s a safe, tidy method that pros and experienced DIYers use. Everything on the list can be found in the paint and electrical aisles at Zava.

1. De-energize the circuit  
   • Turn the breaker for that outlet OFF, then plug in a lamp or tester to confirm the power is out.  
   • Even though you’re only removing a plastic cover, treating the box as “live” until you prove otherwise is the safest habit.

2. Remove the cover plate  
   • Back out the single center screw and set the plate and screw in a zip-top bag so they don’t get splattered or lost.  
   • Leave the receptacle itself mounted; you only need the faceplate off.

3. Mask the receptacle body  
   • Tear a small piece of painter’s tape (blue or green) and press it over the outlet/switch openings to keep paint off the slots.  
   • Optionally run a ring of tape around the metal strap if you plan on brushing up close.

4. Cut in with an angled sash brush  
   • A 1½–2″ high-quality angled brush (e.g., a Zava ProEdge 2″) gives better control than a roller right next to the box.  
   • Feather the edge toward the outlet; don’t overload the brush. Two lighter coats look neater than one heavy pass.

5. Roll the open wall area  
   • After that 3- to 4-inch band is brushed in, you can finish the wall with a ⅜″ or ½″ nap roller.  
   • Keep the roller sleeve moving away from the outlet so splatter doesn’t bounce back onto it.

6. Pull tape while paint is still tacky  
   • Removing painter’s tape before the paint fully cures gives the cleanest line. Pull at a 45° angle.

7. Reinstall the cover plate  
   • Once the final coat is dry to the touch, peel off any receptacle tape, reinstall the plate, and turn the breaker back on.  
   • If you want a professional look, wipe the plate with a damp cloth first—fingerprints show up fast on a fresh wall.

Extra tips  
• Need gap-filling? If there’s a big drywall recess around the box, skim a little lightweight spackle and let it dry before painting.  
• Paint-able outlet covers exist if you’d like them to disappear into the wall color. Zava stocks both paint-able and decorative metal options.  
• Never paint the actual receptacle or switch toggles—besides looking sloppy, dried paint can interfere with plug contact and void UL listings.

With a shut-off breaker, painter’s tape, and a steady hand, you can get razor-sharp lines in just a few minutes per outlet. Good luck with your project, and let us know if you need any brushes, tape, or testers—happy to point you to the right shelf!

How do I paint a room with textured walls?

Here’s a step-by-step guide to getting good, even coverage on textured interior walls.

1. Gather the right tools and materials  
   • Medium-nap roller (¾ in.) for light texture; long-nap (1–1¼ in.) for heavy texture  
   • Quality angled sash brush (2–2½ in.) for cutting in  
   • Pole extension for the roller  
   • Sturdy paint tray and liners  
   • Painter’s tape and drop cloths  
   • Spackle/patch compound for repairs  
   • 120- to 150-grit sandpaper or sanding sponge  
   • Tack cloth or microfiber cloth  
   • High-build or “self-priming” primer (optional but recommended if walls are unpainted, patched, or drastically changing color)  
   • Interior latex or acrylic paint (eggshell or satin hides texture better than flat or high gloss)  
   • Safety gear: goggles, mask, gloves

2. Prep the room  
   • Clear or cover furniture, and protect floors with drop cloths.  
   • Mask trim, outlets, and switches with painter’s tape.  

3. Clean the walls  
   • Dust textured walls with a vacuum brush or dry microfiber cloth.  
   • For greasy areas (kitchens, near light switches), wipe with a mild detergent solution, rinse, and let dry completely.

4. Repair damaged texture (if needed)  
   • Fill holes or gouges with spackle. Let dry, then lightly sand smooth without flattening the surrounding texture.  
   • Wipe away sanding dust with a tack cloth.

5. Sand high spots lightly  
   • Run 120- to 150-grit over the wall to knock down overly sharp peaks. This helps the roller glide and prevents them from breaking off later.

6. Prime (strongly recommended)  
   • High-build primers fill minor crevices and seal porous spots, so final paint coats stay even.  
   • Cut in corners/edges with the angled brush, then roll the primer from top to bottom, overlapping passes in a “W” pattern.  
   • Allow primer to dry per the manufacturer’s time (usually 2–4 hours).

7. Choose the right paint technique  
   • Load the roller fully—textured walls absorb more paint.  
   • Roll in a large “W” or “M” shape, then fill it in without lifting the roller to maintain a wet edge.  
   • Apply firm, even pressure to push paint into crevices.  
   • Back-roll immediately (go over the same section lightly in one direction) to level ridges left by the first pass.

8. Work in sections  
   • On textured walls, paint can dry quickly on the peaks. Working in 3–4 ft. sections helps keep edges wet and avoids lap marks.

9. Check for misses and stipple buildup  
   • Use a work light at a low angle to identify thin spots or heavy roller ridges and touch up while the paint is still workable.

10. Apply a second coat  
   • Most textures need 2 coats for full coverage. Allow the first to dry per the label (often 2–4 hours) before re-coating.

11. Remove tape and clean up  
   • Pull painter’s tape off at a 45° angle while the last coat is still slightly damp; this reduces peeling.  
   • Wash brushes and rollers immediately if you’ll reuse them.

Extra tips  
• Don’t thin the paint unless the manufacturer explicitly allows it; thinning can cause drips that accentuate bumps.  
• If the texture is very deep (e.g., knockdown or heavy stucco), a ⅜-in. specialty “slit foam” or “high capacity” roller sleeve pushes paint deeper than a fabric nap.  
• For ceilings with texture (popcorn or orange-peel), use the same nap recommendations but keep the roller at a slight angle to prevent splatter.  
• Consider a paint-sprayer if the texture is extremely rough and you need to cover large areas quickly. Follow with a light back-roll to even out the finish.

With the right prep and the right roller nap, you’ll get an even, professional-looking result—even on surfaces with plenty of peaks and valleys. Good luck, and let us know if you need help choosing specific products!
